question.title: Why does the java.time.Clock has zone information?
question.body:
Why does java.time.Clock has zone information? From the Clock you only can get an Instant when calling the instant() method - which is a time without zone info.

Is the only purpose to have the zone available in the clock to e.g. create a ZonedDateTime like this? ZonedDateTime.ofInstant(clock().instant(), clock().getZone())

Wouldn't it then make sense to have a method zonedDateTime() in the Clock class?

answers.body:
I suppose it takes a bit of mind reading or guessing to answer your question, but let me try anyway. As far as I can see, the Clock knowing a time zone is very convenient when using any of the now methods taking a Clock argument. None of the following methods could work correctly if the Clock wasn’t able to provide a time zone:

  • LocalDate.now(Clock)
  • LocalDateTime.now(Clock)
  • LocalTime.now(Clock)
  • MonthDay.now(Clock)
  • OffsetDateTime.now(Clock)
  • OffsetTime.now(Clock)
  • Year.now(Clock)
  • YearMonth.now(Clock)
  • ZonedDateTime.now(Clock)
  • HijrahDate.now(Clock)
  • JapaneseDate.now(Clock)
  • MinguoDate.now(Clock)
  • ThaiBuddhistDate.now(Clock)

The list may not be complete. Only Instant.now(Clock) doesn’t need a time zone and ignores the time zone of the Clock.

And yes, the alternative design where Clock had a zonedDateTime method providing the same result as ZonedDateTime.now(Clock) would have made sense too. However: Someone wanting to develop, say, a JewishDate class would never be able to insert a jewishDate method into the Clock class. With the existing design they can design their JewishDate class along the exact same lines as the existing date and time classes, including a JewishDate.now(Clock) method.

Update: In Java 17 the interface InstantSource was added for when you need the clock functionality but don’t need a time zone. That is, you just need to draw instants from the clock. My mind-reading abilities, if I have any at all, tell me that the designers have happened to ask themselves the same question that you asked here.

InstantSource

First, some information that is not the answer: For many purposes, when you find yourself using a Clock, you would be better served using an InstantSource in Java 17+. These do not have a ZoneId.

The InstantSource interface provides static factories similar to those provided by Clock. If all you need is a source of Instants, use InstantSource.system() (or tick or whatever,) instead.

If you find yourself asking the question I'll be answering below, you probably don't need a Clock.

But to answer the question: instances of Clock are meant to be passed as arguments into other java.time.* functions that need both an InstantSource and a ZoneId. It is just meant to be used as a convenience wrapper because there are so many functions that need those two things. (Whether that's a good design is open to question.)

So, Clock isn't really meant to be used on its own to provide Instants. If that's all you need, use an InstantSource instead.
